Just wrapped our earnings call and wanted to share a few highlights from the quarter. 
Bottom line: We‚Äôve got great momentum across our AI platform and our family of Copilots,¬†fueling our increasing investments in both capital and talent.
We‚Äôre building a planet-scale cloud and AI factory.
We‚Äôll increase our AI capacity by 80% this year, and nearly double our DC footprint over the next two.
That includes Fairwater in Wisconsin, the world‚Äôs most powerful AI datacenter, which will scale to two gigawatts alone.
We are building a fungible fleet that spans every stage of the AI lifecycle and is constantly optimized to deliver the best ROI and TCO for us and our customers.
One example: during the quarter, we increased the token throughput for GPT-4.1 and GPT-5 by more than 30% per GPU.
Our family of Copilots and agents also surpassed over 150 million monthly active users across high value domains:
‚Ä¢ Information work: 90 percent of the F500 now use Microsoft 365 Copilot ‚Äì and we‚Äôre shipping updates very fast
‚Ä¢ Coding: GitHub Copilot now has 26 million-plus users
‚Ä¢ Security: 36+ agents integrated across Entra, Defender, Purview, Intune
‚Ä¢ Science & Health: We helped document 17 million-plus patient encounters, up 5X year over year
‚Ä¢ Consumer: Tons of new capabilities announced over the past two weeks, from Groups and Mico in Copilot, to "Hey Copilot" in Windows
And this week, we signed a new agreement with OpenAI, a milestone for both companies. 
It‚Äôs been an incredible investment, with nearly 10X return and no carry. All the value goes straight to shareholders.
Another thing I feel super proud about is that Microsoft is now behind two of the largest nonprofits in the world!
You can read more about our results here: https://lnkd.in/gxtVeMk2

What a week last week was in Cambridge.
From ‚ÄòIdeas to Reality‚Äô to ‚ÄòSPARK 1.0‚Äô to ‚ÄòBioCentury Grand Rounds‚Äô to ‚ÄòCambridge Tech Week‚Äô it has been a powerful reminder of what is at the core of this ecosystem.
At @Cambridge Enterprise‚Äôs Ideas to Reality, we welcomed attendees from across the Cambridge ecosystem and beyond to celebrate the incredible innovation emerging from the University. The twisting path from an early innovation to transformational societal impact was laid bare. As such, Cambridge Enterprise has a diverse toolkit to support founders who are tackling global challenges. The energy in the room was electrifying and carried me throughout the rest of the week.
At the SPARK 1.0 Demo Day, a programme created by @Kings E-Lab in partnership with @Founders at the University of Cambridge, I was fortunate to witness 22 ventures from across 17 University departments pitch bold ideas, from climate tech to digital health, to a room full of investors, advisors and peers. The drive, collaboration and ambition on display captured the spirit of Cambridge perfectly.
Meanwhile, @BioCentury Inc. Grand Rounds brought leading life science investors, academics and biopharma leaders to the city and @Cambridge Tech Week showcased the visionaries and specialists behind Cambridge‚Äôs thriving tech ecosystem.
This is a truly special ecosystem, with an exceptional degree of connection and support amongst all stakeholders, and one that I am proud to be a part of.

What happens when a San Francisco VC takes the reins at Cambridge Enterprise?
Six months into the role, Jim Glasheen joins us to talk about his early moves as incoming CEO, like opening a London office to better plug Cambridge into global capital and talent flows. But this episode goes deeper than strategy.
üîë Key takeaways:
‚Ä¢ Cambridge has over 40 entrepreneurship programmes, but Jim questions if we‚Äôre at risk of creating an ‚Äúillusion of entrepreneurship‚Äù without real market pressure.
‚Ä¢ There‚Äôs a persistent Series B funding gap. His push? Build international investor relationships before companies need to scale.
‚Ä¢ He wants the ecosystem to get more comfortable with failure and take on more risk. 
‚Ä¢ Cambridge Enterprise now spans licensing, founder support, venture investment, consulting, and ecosystem-building.
Jim‚Äôs set the clock ticking: in 6 months, he‚Äôll report back on how international outreach and risk appetite are shifting. For now, he's off to the BIO conference in Boston to keep building those global ties.
üéß Listen in for a sharp, honest look at what Cambridge needs next, and how leadership is setting the tone.

With less than two weeks to go, Nigeria Solar Forum will convene the key players driving investment and development in Nigerian renewables, with a core focus on forging deals, shaping policies, and building the partnerships that will power Nigeria's energy future. The event will focus exclusively on Nigeria's renewable energy market realities, policies, challenges, and opportunities, rather than offering a broad, pan-African sweep, it zeroes in on the unique drivers of Nigeria's solar revolution.

When we started AnimalKind, we knew the hard part wouldn't be finding practices looking to exit. It would be finding people who think and operate the same way we do. 
People who want to build something that lasts. Who care about doing it properly, not just doing it quickly. Who see collaboration as the point, not the obstacle.
James Weston is one of those people. Over our conversations, it became clear we were after the same thing, a group built on the right foundations, with the patience to let it compound over time.
Today, Northwest Referrals joins AnimalKind. James stays as Managing Director and joins us as a Director.
There's a version of veterinary consolidation that burns people out and strips practices of what made them good. We're trying to prove there's another way. That you can build a successful business while maintaining the right ethos. That good people want to be part of something like that.
This is early proof. Plenty more to do.
Thank you to all our partners, advisors, shareholders and investors who helped us get this over the line.
‚Ä¶more
AnimalKind
AnimalKind
112 followers
112 followers
Veterinary consolidation has a particular reputation. Practices acquired, identities lost, teams stretched thin.
We set up AnimalKind to do it differently: 
1- Partner with good people and holistically develop our teams. 
2- Keep local names and double down on community connection. 
3- Support what's already working and amplify it with technology when it makes sense. 
4- Take the long view.
James Weston built Northwest Referrals in Wigan, a fantastic team of 35 people with advanced-practitioner expertise, and fixed pricing that gives clients clarity from the start. He chose to work with us because of how we connect with our teams, our company charter and the direction we're headed. 
Today, Northwest Referrals joins AnimalKind. James stays as Managing Director and joins us as a Director. Same name. Same team. Same commitment to all our clients and communities.
This is what we mean by doing things differently. We're building something good people want to be part of. A group that others are excited to join. 
Read more: https://lnkd.in/dqUK36q6
Thanks to Shawbrook for Healthcare, HCR Law, and Hazlewoods for their support, as well as all of our trusted shareholders and investors.

After starting off in finance, I took the plunge into tech entrepreneurship in 2016, founding a real-time restaurant deals app called CityMunch. We had a good run until the pandemic, with around 80k Londoners and 20k Bristolians using the app, and helping around 400 restaurants fill their quieter times with more customers.

After a bit of a hiatus over the Christmas period, the Old Street Labs podcast is back with a bang. And I couldn‚Äôt have picked a better conversation to return with.
This week on the podcast, I‚Äôm joined by Lucy Woodhead, VP of Operations at US Jetting (and also my lovely cousin!)
This is not your typical ‚Äútech business‚Äù. US Jetting is a second generation manufacturing company operating in a tough, very physical industry. And yet, they‚Äôre actively embracing technology, from process and ops improvements through to e-commerce and digital platforms.
We talked about what it really takes to modernise a business like this without losing what makes it work in the first place.
We got into:
‚Ä¢ Moving from fashion into operations in an industrial environment
‚Ä¢ What it‚Äôs actually like working inside a family run business
‚Ä¢ Bringing structure and process to messy, real-world operations
‚Ä¢ Designing digital experiences for very different customer needs
‚Ä¢ Helping small businesses feel confident using technology
‚Ä¢ A thoughtful, practical take on AI in a non-tech-first industry
‚Ä¢ Leadership, growth, and learning on the job
It‚Äôs a great reminder that some of the most interesting tech stories aren‚Äôt coming from shiny startups, but from established businesses quietly evolving and doing the hard work of change.

2022‚Äôs interest rate rollercoaster ride has taken one more upward lurch, with the Bank of England delivering another blow in its battle to bring down inflation. This latest hike will wrap up the most aggressive year of monetary policy in four decades. We know it has caused weariness and uncertainty across financial markets, and many are now casting their eyes forward to what 2023 might have in store. 
On a more positive note, yesterday‚Äôs CPI data suggest that the inflation fever might be starting to break, which could translate into smaller interest rate increments over the next year. Financial markets had priced in a peak of 6% for the base rate at one point, but signs suggest it might not reach these heights. Nevertheless, as the UK enters into recession, agility, diversification and foresight will be key in injecting resilience into investment portfolios and minimising investors' exposure to the current macroeconomic headwinds. 
With investors juggling risk and opportunity, it should be expected that many will look to balance traditional and alternative investments. Moreover, in light of the recent Autumn Statement, it is likely that tax-efficient investments will see greater demand. I would also expect real estate to remain high on investors‚Äô wish lists, even as house prices recalibrate, with the latest stamp duty cuts likely to increase the market‚Äôs resilience in the face of the wider economic turbulence.

PLEASE everyone donate money, toys, sensory equipment this really is special and needed for the children and their families 
The Joshua Tree offers respite and support to children with cancer and their families, from the initial diagnosis, through treatment and beyond.
The children have access to play spaces, activities and therapy, whilst parents and siblings are encouraged to unwind with talking therapy, complementary treatments or PT sessions.
The charity was set up 20 years ago by Dai and Lynda Hill after they found limited support for their own family when their 5 year old son Joshua was diagnosed with Leukemia. Joshua now helps out with PT sessions for children and teens to encourage them back to fitness after treatment.
The charity is currently supporting more than 300 families from the local area but the demand for the service they offer is increasing nationwide as families travel further to access treatment from nearby Alder Hey and Manchester Children‚Äôs Hospital.
DIY SOS & Children in Need invites all trades, volunteers and suppliers to help support our build for this amazing charity, so they can expand and continue the life changing work they already do.

Galliard Homes in Joint Venture with DS Real Estate is delighted to announce that the Planning Inspector has granted approval for the redevelopment of The Point, 602 Midsummer Boulevard, Milton Keynes.
Our plans will transform this prominent site, which has been vacant for nearly 20 years, into a dynamic mixed-use destination. The scheme delivers up to 500 new homes, including Build to Rent and private sale, along with flexible ground floor leisure and retail space.
At the heart of the proposals is a commitment to celebrating the legacy of The Point. The development will include landscaped public spaces such as ‚ÄúThe Setting Space‚Äù and ‚ÄúThe Gateway Garden‚Äù to encourage community activity and connection. Feature lighting will recreate Milton Keynes‚Äô iconic beacon, paying homage to the site‚Äôs heritage while ushering in a bold new chapter for the city centre.
The multi-storey car park will be re-clad and modernised, incorporating a striking rooftop leisure hub with a bar, restaurant and outdoor sports spaces. This ambitious project will revitalise a key location in central Milton Keynes, delivering homes, jobs and vibrant public spaces for residents and visitors to enjoy.
We look forward to working with Milton Keynes Council, local stakeholders and the wider community as we bring this vision to life.
Reflex Property Finance Charlie Banner (Lord Banner KC) Spencer Tewis-Allen Jeremy Pickard Laurie Handcock

About
I am the Founder and CEO of Learnutec Technology Academy, an innovative IT training institution dedicated to preparing the next generation of Microsoft Cloud professionals. In this role, I lead the strategic direction of the academy, oversee curriculum development, manage instructor-led programs, and drive partnerships that support student career outcomes and employer needs. My goal is to make high-quality, hands-on technical education accessible to individuals looking to launch or elevate careers in IT.
With over 30+ years of experience in the information technology industry, I bring a deep technical foundation and a passion for teaching. My career has spanned roles from hardware and software deployment engineer to networking consultant and Microsoft Certified Trainer, working with global technology leaders including ICL Fujitsu, HP, IBM, Dell, Cisco, Citrix, and Microsoft.
I have delivered IT solutions and training across the UK, Europe, Africa, and the US, serving clients such as the British Ministry of Defence, Texaco, and various private-sector organisations. This international exposure has shaped my global outlook on technology education and digital transformation.
Today, I specialise in guiding individuals and organisations through their transition to Microsoft Cloud technologies. Through Learnutec, I provide virtual and instructor-led training focused on Azure and Microsoft 365 platforms, helping learners achieve certification and workplace readiness.

On Monday night, BBC Panorama aired an investigation that revealed some eye-opening findings about supermarket price-matching. They found that many of Tesco‚Äôs products, which claim to be price-matched with Aldi, are not like-for-like. 
The programme, which aired on BBC One, highlighted that nearly a third of Tesco‚Äôs matched products contain less of the main ingredient compared to Aldi‚Äôs. This really reinforces what we‚Äôve always believed: Aldi is the only supermarket where you can count on both top-quality products and low prices.
At Aldi, we believe that fresh, healthy, great-quality food is a right, not a privilege. That‚Äôs why we‚Äôre so committed to bringing our customers the best at the most affordable prices. And while we put all our energy into maintaining these standards, we‚Äôre aware that no one is perfect, including ourselves. We are always striving to improve, and we welcome feedback from our valued customers to help us do just that.
We‚Äôre aware that other retailers might claim to match our prices, but as this research shows, these claims are not always what they appear to be. We welcome the investigation by Panorama, as it supports what we passionately believe: at Aldi, you don‚Äôt have to compromise on quality to get great value.
We work tirelessly to ensure our exclusive products are not only affordable but meet the highest standards, often with a higher specification than equivalent own-label products sold by our competitors. About
About
Developing candidates and their talents, empowering people and businesses to succeed, and advancing the digital transformation in the world of work. That is my passion. 
Working at Hays for over 25 years, I started off as a department and division manager in Germany, continuing as Director of Sales, later Chief Operating Officer, Chief Executive Officer for Germany and CEMEA, and now CEO of Hays plc. 
Communication, business strategy, and culture is very important to me. I believe the personnel challenges of the future can best be solved through exchange of ideas, especially in turbulent times like these. I'm looking forward to sharing insights regularly into my work as CEO, and the developments in our company on LinkedIn.

We‚Äôre delighted to welcome Mark Dearnley to Hays as our new Chief Digital and Technology Officer and a member of our Executive Leadership Team.
Mark joins us at a pivotal moment in our journey. As part of our global strategy to build a more resilient, profitable, and growing Hays, we are committed to investing in innovation, digitisation, and data. This is fundamental as we evolve our business and continue to deliver an exceptional service to our customers worldwide.
With extensive experience leading digital and IT transformation across global organisations in telecoms, retail, consulting, and the public sector, Mark brings a proven track record of using technology to enhance customer experience, drive innovation, and deliver meaningful outcomes.
At Hays, we believe the future of work lies in the powerful combination of¬†human expertise and digital innovation. Finally, I‚Äôd like to thank Tim Fulton, our outgoing Chief Technology Officer, for his outstanding leadership over the past two years. The hype is real - PEG¬Æ is on the rise - 
thanks to its intentionally engineered simplicity! üí° 
There is currently a clear trend in the industry toward ultra-light, sustainable, and economical system designs for large solar and battery storage projects such as Jurchen Technology GmbH's PEG¬Æ. This is currently highlighted by an online article of Renew Economy from autor Sophie Vorrath about a new project in the South Burnett region of Queensland that focuses on precisely these requirements. 
The key message of the article is: 
the advantages of PEG¬Æ are obvious!
¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†PEG¬Æ does not require concrete - no heavy foundations
¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†PEG¬Æ reduces material and logistics costs
¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†PEG¬Æ enables quick installation - with standard hand tools. 
¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†PEG¬Æ stands for high land utilization and low visual impact. 
¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†PEG¬Æ optimizes the cost-effectiveness of projects. (Fewer machines, less logistics, less steel, and shorter construction phases mean lower overall costs and reduced risks).
Projects such as the one in Queensland highlight the importance of substructures - like the highly efficient PEG¬Æ solar mounting system - for the energy transition in terms of sustainability, approvability, and cost-effectiveness.

With over 15 years of experience in AI product development across various industries and academia, I am passionate about leveraging artificial intelligence to drive innovation and impact.
My career began as a data scientist at pSeven, where I developed AI products for industry leaders such as Airbus, IHI, Mitsubishi, and even a Formula 1 team.

When I joined PageGroup as a consultant in 1995, we were a company operating in just 6 countries, with a dedicated team of 600. Fast forward 28 years, and we've grown into a truly global organisation of 8,600 talented individuals, spanning 37 dynamic markets. 
As I look back on our remarkable journey, I am immensely proud of everything our incredible team has achieved. It's testament to our unwavering commitment to the success of our clients, candidates and employees. 
Last week, the Executive Board and I unveiled PageGroup's new strategy that will guide us through to 2030. This strategy builds upon our existing strengths and focuses on what we‚Äôre famous for. 
Our path forward will be defined by a set of strategic goals designed to unlock our full potential and amplify our impact.¬†These are based around delivering an ambitious operating profit, driving social impact by changing one million lives, and offering best-in-class customer experience. 
Our approach centres around maximising our core business and building on our market-leading position. Additionally, we'll leverage our existing global platforms and harness the 
hashtag
#PowerofPage, expanding our technology recruitment business, growing Page Executive, and nurturing strategic partnerships, seizing opportunities that will allow us to stand out in specific areas and markets. 
Enabling our success, we will draw on the global technology and insights platforms now in place and used every day by our teams worldwide. Our investments in these areas mean we are well positioned to leverage opportunities globally across our business in innovation, especially when it comes to AI. 
I am looking forward to this exciting new chapter in PageGroup's history and leading a business that is customer led, people powered, and insights driven. 
Thank you to our incredible team and partners for being part of this journey. Together, we will continue to achieve our ambitious targets and make a meaningful impact.

Rentd is a tech-powered rental platform designed to make renting smarter, fairer, and more rewarding. For renters, it offers a seamless way to find and secure homes, while turning rent payments into real value through its innovative rewards card, helping renters get more back from their biggest monthly expense. The platform ensures transparency, ease of use, and financial benefits that go beyond traditional renting.
For landlords, Rentd provides direct access to a wide pool of verified renters, while ensuring on-time, secure payments through its integrated system. With powerful digital tools to manage listings, streamline communication, and maximise occupancy, landlords save time while reducing risk.
Together, Rentd is building a future where renting works better for everyone, creating lasting value for both renters and landlords.

Chantal is a global business leader with over 25 years experience in leading successful businesses, frequently in transformation. She leads through strategic mindset, client focused approach, technology adoption and shrewd financial discipline.
Chantal joined Ocorian, a global leader in fund administration, capital markets, corporate and fiduciary services, as CEO in September 2023. The organisation manage over 15,000 structures on behalf of 8,000+ clients, including financial institutions, large-scale international organisations and high-net-worth individuals, across more than 20 jurisdictions. 
Prior to joining Ocorian, Chantal was CEO for Capita‚Äôs Portfolio Division. The division comprised of over 30 businesses that were considered non-core to Capita and were exited over a two year period. Chantal's role included leading these businesses successfully as well as preparing them for and executing upon their disposals. She took on this role after leading Capita's People Solutions division (a ¬£600m division comprising various HR businesses) for about two years.
Prior to joining Capita, Chantal held a number of senior roles at Willis Towers Watson, with her last role being the leadership of the Human Capital & Benefits business in Western Europe.
Chantal graduated from Imperial College, London with an MBA and spent her professional career in Europe and in Asia. She speaks a number of European languages. She also has the privilege to serve as a Governor of Latymer Upper School and as Trustee of the Latymer Foundation.

You can‚Äôt bolt automation onto a rubbish pile and expect magic...
I‚Äôve been implementing more AI internally and having pretty regular conversations with providers ‚Äì about 4 or 5 a month.
If I'm honest, lots of them¬†are doing similar things. 
And the position I keep coming back to is: none of it really matters unless your data is clean, structured, and built properly.
So, the real question is ‚Äì what are we selling that an internal recruitment function with AI can‚Äôt replicate?
For us, it‚Äôs our dataset, IP, and our¬†team‚Äôs market insight, context and judgement.
AI will keep levelling up, and when it does, we‚Äôll innovate again to stay ahead. That‚Äôs¬†more exciting than daunting in my opinion.
I‚Äôve shared some more thoughts you can read here: 
https://lnkd.in/edfaigbF

Just wanted to shout out Zac Turner for his unreal start at the business. I think its safe to say, changing market specificity after 10 years in industry would be daunting for anyone. But one thing that is essential in getting up and running in a new vertical is perseverance. 
I am sure Zac wouldn't mind me saying that there were a lot of long nights and set backs, especially in first 3 months, to get him to where he is now. Going from a business leader to a learner of a new market is a difficult thing for some people to comprehend. This requires a few things, but most importantly, leaving the ego at the door. I think anyone who has met Zac inside the business will say his humility so far has been admirable. 
One thing we have now got an excellent track record of across the business is recruiting from other markets and integrating them into high performing teams internally. We are currently hiring across a few business units internally both in London and Miami, and as ever, we are considering people to change market. 
If you would be interested in hearing about what a market change could look like for you, please reach out.

1mo ‚Ä¢ Edited ‚Ä¢ 
1 month ago ‚Ä¢ Edited ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
A sense of balance is important in business - I know we‚Äôve achieved a lot with Octopus Energy and Kraken - and I‚Äôm intensely proud of that - but I also know we‚Äôre far from perfect.
If I post about customer service - inevitably (and totally rightly) some customers will post comments about where we‚Äôve gone wrong. If I post about tech, people will rightly highlight weaknesses.
And internally, I caution the team about getting high on their own supply - we should be proud and confident but humble about where others are better - not just because there‚Äôs a fine line between pride and arrogance, but otherwise how do we learn, improve and grow?
When we get compliments I‚Äôm usually quick to mention our shortcomings, and I won‚Äôt allow us to be described as ‚Äúsuccessful‚Äù (as Kenny Rogers put it - "never count your money when you're sitting at the table").
So I rarely feel unalloyed joy. Indeed, there‚Äôve been three moments of uncaveated pride in the history of our company.
One was when we first became a unicorn, and could deliver on the promise to our team - all of whom are shareholders, and many took a risk on a startup with big ambitions (a lot of mums and dads quizzed them why they were joining an unknown company with a dozen people in a small office in Hammersmith. This justified their faith). I was equally proud when Al Gore‚Äôs fund invested - and we introduced him to the entire company on Zoom - the emoji reactions told me that the team felt the way I did.
And last week - among some of the most impressive businesses in the UK, Octopus was named Britain‚Äôs Most Admired Company (https://lnkd.in/etAr-d_y).
No caveats (‚Äúmost admired young company‚Äù or ‚Äúmost admired tech company‚Äù or whatever) simply ‚Äúmost admired company‚Äù.
I stood there next to the Most Admired Leader (Tufan Erginbilgi√ß) at the London Stock Exchange and really felt this was a coming of age for our business.
It capped a remarkable few weeks. We‚Äôd announced the demerger of Kraken - we‚Äôd built it from nothing and now it‚Äôs a fantastic $9bn monster - freed to meet its full potential (I‚Äôll write about that soon!) And we‚Äôd learned that we‚Äôd been awarded Which? Recommended for the 9th year in a row. Which? Is just about the most stringent award you can win - and to do so 9 years in a row is huge external recognition for the work our team do for customers.
So - we‚Äôre not perfect - but I did take a deep breath (it was a breathtaking moment) - and decide it was ok to enjoy a moment of pride. Before setting off back to the office with a renewed sense or purpose, and huge pride in what our team have built. But I‚Äôm not gonna lie - it felt good. And I think that‚Äôs ok, just occasionally.

Navigating Change: How Collaboration and Resilience Transformed Our Workplace 
(Continuation from part 1)
With a busy day planned ahead, she realized the necessity of prioritizing her health, especially given the strenuous demands of her job. A balanced diet was not just essential for energy, but also for mental clarity and emotional stability. Wrapped in a towel and feeling refreshed, she reflected on her meals for the next day. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt let convenience compromise my health,‚Äù she resolved.
The next morning, Maritime awoke with a sense of purpose. She rushed to the kitchen with a plan in mind. She decided to whip up a nutritious breakfast scrambling eggs packed with protein alongside whole grain toast and fresh fruit. Each bite was a reminder that she could nourish her body, setting a positive tone for her day.
As she prepared to head to work, she made a mental note to prep a colorful salad for lunch. Filled with leafy greens, healthy fats, and lean protein, it was a delicious way to fuel herself for the tasks that lay ahead. She recognized that taking a bit of extra time to prepare healthy meals was not a burden but an investment in her well-being.
Maritime embraced this commitment to herself. She understood that nourishing her body would bolster her mental resilience against stress, allowing her to tackle challenges with renewed vigor. With every healthy choice, she felt a growing empowerment.
Climbing into bed that night, Maritime was filled with a profound sense of accomplishment. She was learning the significance of self-care, healthy eating, and rest. Each new day was an opportunity-an opportunity not just to survive, but to truly thrive. As she drifted off to sleep, she felt optimistic about the journey ahead, ready to face whatever challenges came her way with vitality and strength.

Shaheen Sayed is the Head of Accenture‚Äôs UK, Ireland and Africa business (UKIA) and is a member of Accenture‚Äôs Global Management Committee. 
In her role, Shaheen has overall responsibility for the growth and success of Accenture‚Äôs business in the regions.¬†She oversees a wide range of functions, from strategy & consulting to technology, operations and Accenture Song, ensuring that Accenture delivers high-value services to its clients.¬† Accenture is a major local employer in all three markets and also has a strong innovation footprint through R&D and investment including its brand-new AI experience studios in London and Dublin and our global innovation centre, The Dock, based in Ireland.
Prior to this role, Shaheen led the Technology business in the UK and Ireland, specialising in complex technology and business transformations and pioneering new market technologies. The last thing any leader needs in 2026 is another framework to navigate.
If you feel like you‚Äôre drowning in acronyms and reporting standards, you aren‚Äôt alone. Framework fatigue is real, and it‚Äôs often the biggest barrier to actual progress.
The truth is, most organisations already have the data and the tools they need. What‚Äôs missing isn‚Äôt more structure: it‚Äôs the capacity to make sense of it all.
At Greenheart, we don‚Äôt believe in adding complexity for the sake of it. Our role isn‚Äôt to hand you a new manual; it‚Äôs to help you join the dots between the ones you already have.
When we partner with leadership teams, we focus on integration over accumulation. We look at how your B Corp commitments, your climate transition plans and your strategic goals can stop competing for attention and start working as one single, resilient operating system.
That‚Äôs when the magic happens.
We love nothing more than giving you the clarity to do less, but better. We aim to give you the confidence to evolve from ‚Äòmanaging‚Äô sustainability reports to actually running a high-performing, resilient and future-proof business.
We‚Äôre here to reduce the load, not add to it. Because a strategy that lives in a binder is just a waste of everyone‚Äôs time. Whereas a plan that lives in your day-to-day decision-making? That‚Äôs resilience.
What acronyms or reporting standards would you ban right now??

About
About
Head Building Surveyor at STEND, I lead a team of professionals in delivering high-quality building surveys, stock condition surveys, project management, and building design services. We work with a diverse range of clients, from social housing providers to commercial developers, to make the built environment safer, more efficient, and sustainable.
I have a BSc in Building Surveying from the University of Wolverhampton, and I am an Undergraduate Member of the Chartered Institute of Building (RICS). I have over 6 years of experience in the industry, working for reputable firms such as Currie & Brown and Calfordseaden. I have developed core competencies in building surveying, social housing, dilapidations, and Spanish language. I am passionate about precision and client satisfaction, and I am always eager to learn and grow. Let's connect and explore how we can work together to elevate your property assets. You can reach me at donald@starttoend.co.uk.
